intro: Mariscus brittonii, commonly known as the Britton's mariscus, is a rare and delicate flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and umbel-shaped flower clusters. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils in arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. Its small, white or pale pink flowers bloom in the spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Mariscus brittonii is considered a species of conservation concern.
